data.name: F-score
data.description:
## Overview

Imagine that you work as a Data Scientist and you are tasked with creating an algorithm that will classify a huge amount of data. But how do we test the accuracy of that algorithm?

There are many ways to do this. In our case, we will use such a popular thing as [F-score](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score).

The input will be a ready report of the algorithm. Based on this information you will need to write an F-score function that will evaluate the performance of the algorithm.

To calculate the F-score use the formula:

* ```math
\displaystyle F = 2\cdot \frac{\mathrm{precision} \cdot \mathrm{recall}}{\mathrm{precision} + \mathrm{recall}}
```

To calculate precision and recall use the formulas:
* ```math
\displaystyle \mathrm{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP+FP}
```
* ```math
\displaystyle \mathrm{Recall} = \frac{TP}{TP+FN}
```

**Note:**
If one of the `TP+FP` or `TP+FN` is zero, then the F-score should be zero. But if both values are zero, the function should return 0.5 (because the accuracy will be 50%).
Also, if *Precision* and *Recall* are zero, F-score should return zero

### Input:

There are 4 values at the input:
* `TP` (True Positive) - values that were correctly classified as positive
* `FP` (False Positive) - values that were correctly classified as negative
* `TN` (True Negative) - values that were wrongly classified as positive
* `FN` (False Negative) - values that were wrongly classified as negative

Happy coding :)
